name: Classical Axioms: Peirce's Law-Equivalent
description:
_Note to translators: This Kata is **NOT** accepting any translations to Coq / Lean / Agda due to the huge difference in difficulty between Idris and those languages mentioned. Any translations violating this rule will be rejected without further reason._

***

This kata was taken from Coq'Art book by Bertot and Casteran (p. 123). 

The goal is to prove that all six propositions are equivalent.

```idris
Peirce : Type 
Peirce = (a : Type) -> (b : Type) -> ((a -> b) -> a) -> a

ExcludedMiddle : Type 
ExcludedMiddle = (a : Type) -> Either a (Not a)

DoubleNegationElim : Type 
DoubleNegationElim = (a : Type) -> Not (Not a) -> a 

Absurdity : Type 
Absurdity = (a : Type) -> (b : Type) -> (Not a -> Not b) -> b -> a 

DeMorganNotAndNot : Type 
DeMorganNotAndNot = (a : Type) -> (b : Type) -> Not (Not a, Not b) -> Either a b

ImpliesToOr : Type 
ImpliesToOr = (a : Type) -> (b : Type) -> (a -> b) -> Either (Not a) b
```

To prove these are equivalent, the simplest way is to form a closed loop of the implication relationship. Just like given in the initial solution: 

```idris
proof1 : Peirce -> ExcludedMiddle
proof2 : ExcludedMiddle -> DoubleNegationElim
proof3 : DoubleNegationElim -> Absurdity
proof4 : Absurdity -> DeMorganNotAndNot
proof5 : DeMorganNotAndNot -> ImpliesToOr
proof6 : ImpliesToOr -> Peirce
```

Of course, you could choose any order you prefer to construct proof1~6. For example, if you have already proved `lemma1 : Peirce -> DoubleNegationElim` and `lemma2 : DoubleNegationElim -> ExcludedMiddle`, just write proof1 as: `proof1 = lemma2 . lemma1`. 

Fare thee well.
